identificationModule.briefTitle: Robot Assisted Gait Training in Patients With Infratentorial Stroke
identificationModule.officialTitle: The Effect of Robot Assisted Gait Training in Patients With Infratentorial Stroke

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The Effect of Robot Assisted Gait Training in Patients With Infratentorial Stroke
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: The hypothesis is to determine the robotic gait training would be better than conventional therapy regarding the postural balance.

armGroups.label: Robot, then conventional training
armGroups.description: Robot assisted gait training 4 weeks after conventional gait training

armGroups.label: Conventional, then robot training
armGroups.description: Conventional gait training 4 weeks after robot assisted gait training

interventions.name: Robot, then conventional training
interventions.description: Robot assisted gait training from the baseline, then conventional gait training at 4 weeks after baseline

interventions.name: Conventional, then robot training
interventions.description: Conventional gait training from the baseline, then robot assisted gait training at 4 weeks after baseline

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change From Baseline in Berg Balance Scale at 4 Weeks

secondaryOutcomes.description: Trunk impairment scale performs to evaluate the sitting balance and trunk control ability examining static sitting balance, dynamic sitting balance, and coordination

secondaryOutcomes.description: Each subject performs the following four tasks resembling Romberg test: standing with their feet positioning with the distance between their shoulders with eyes open (FSEO) or closed (FSEC), and standing with their feet together with eyes open (FTEO) or closed (FTEC). Each task is performed for 20 seconds and repeat for three times.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Patients with infratentorial stroke
* Cognitively intact enough to understand and follow the instructions from the investigator

Exclusion Criteria:

* chronic neurological pathology
* orthopedic injuries
* femur lengths of less than 34cm
* severely limited range of lower extremity joint motion
* medical instability

references.citation: Kim HY, Shin JH, Yang SP, Shin MA, Lee SH. Robot-assisted gait training for balance and lower extremity function in patients with infratentorial stroke: a single-blinded randomized controlled trial. J Neuroeng Rehabil. 2019 Jul 29;16(1):99. doi: 10.1186/s12984-019-0553-5.
